article: For centuries, magicians have used various ways to shock the audience. We all have seen how a _ performer carefully steps _ a bed of burning coals -- barefoot. Then he walks across _ a single burn on his feet. Is it mind over matter, or is it just physics? As it turns _ , walking on burning coals isn't that hot as imagined . "The coals are hot enough to _ you, but if you walk quickly across them you _ being burned." says Jonathan Hall, a physician at Penn State University in Eric Pennsylvania. That's because some coals are made _ burning wood chips. Wood has two _ properties for fire-walking, explains Hall. First, wood is an insulator --it doesn't _ heat very well. "It _ time for heat to travel _ the wood to your feet." Hall says. If the performer walked across red-hot metal _ , that would truly be _ , because metal conducts, or transmits, heat very well. The metal would _ burn a performer's feet. Second, wood has a low specific heat-- it doesn't take much heat to _ its temperature. Heat is a form of _ . Temperature is a _ of heat, in units of degrees. So even though the coals are hot, the value of heat energy they contain is low. Thus, a well-trained performer can _ such an amazing result. Still, you don't want to walk on burning coals, do you?
